Comment:
Hi everyone, just for once it is me that gets those pawns rolling!  This game against my buddy Bob Jacobs, a player less than 100 points south of my rating, is very even until well into the late middlegame when a pile up on the c file of my heavies leads to me winning a pawn due to a pin on his dark square bishop.  After that I still end up with work to do.  One big dilemma that I was faced with was "Should Glenda abandon the c file to the Wicked Witch of the West and if so, where should she go?"  Thankfully that dilemma was somehow sorted with Glenda able to go back to that file.  A queen swap followed and I had a strong wall of passers.  It seemed plain sailing, but, I ask, when is a jstevens1 victory plain sailing?  Not often.  In the end, a knight move enabled me to put the advanced queenside pawns just where I wanted them.  Even him giving up his dsb would not have prevented a joyous reunion between Glenda and Henry so he waved the white flag.

He kicks off with the Caro-Kann Defense and I respond with the exchange variation hoping for open play.

After that I still end up with work to do.  One big dilemma that I was faced with was "Should Glenda abandon the c file to the Wicked Witch of the West and if so, where should she go?"  Thankfully that dilemma was somehow sorted with Glenda able to go back to that file.  A queen swap followed and I had a strong wall of passers.  It seemed plain sailing, but, I ask, when is a jstevens1 victory plain sailing?  Not often.  In the end, a knight move enabled me to put the advanced queenside pawns just where I wanted them.  Even him giving up his dsb would not have prevented a joyous reunion between Glenda and Henry so he waved the white flag.

9. 0-0 - fairly routine development up to here.  My queen knight has a dual function, to give additional back up to my f3 knight and to contest the enemy knight's control of e4.  Henry is now tucked up in bed.

12. ......... bxc6 - a few exchanges have cleared the position a bit.  I didn't think that my e5 knight would be able to remain on that square for that much longer so I decided to trade it in.  At least the knight exchange leaves Bob with a queenside isolani which will weigh against him later on.

18. Nf3 - after a plethora of exchanges my knight drops back to f3 to cover the d4 pawn.  Black may have a slight edge here.  He now advances to a5 and this becomes an unfortunate choice of square for that poor little black pawn.

22. Qd2 - Oh dear, now my d4 pawn is an isolani.  Thankfully this does not present too much of a problem but there is going to be some shuffling around of my heavies.  In the middlegame I am often faced with "Where do I go from here?"  Well, that c file just needs to have a white rook on it before black gets the chance to bag it first.  Glenda supports the c1-c3 squares as well as the d4 pawn so that makes it ideal for a doubling, even trippling on that file.  Note that if the a8 rook moves off the a file the black pawn on a5 is up for grabs.

38. Qc5 - Glenda is allowed to move onto the c file and now a queen trade is forced.  Although it allowes black a d pawn passer I now have 3 queenside passers.  The knight on f3 now becomes a knight in shining armour to me.

42. Nd4 - d-d-d-l-d-d!! In gallops the knight.  He is heading for b3 to stop the enemy king invading on c5 should the pawn chain remain on a4, b5 and c6.

45. Kf1 - in the endgame it is vital for the king to be centralised, even more so here.  Black starts a pawn roll of his own and both Henry and his steed must work together to contain them as well as protect that vital pawn wall on the queenside.
